intro: Trachymene novoguineensis, commonly known as the New Guinea false shamrock, is a flowering plant native to New Guinea. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers arranged in umbrella-like clusters, a feature typical of the carrot family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in tropical rainforests. Due to its ornamental value and unique appearance, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and by plant enthusiasts.
